Seven Principles of Design

There are really lots of useful ways to categorize and talk about design. You could come up with any arbitrary way of grouping these topics together, listing them out, and exploring them.

# 

<span key="ee592e56638e47f4950bda3bdefd08d7"><span offset-key="ee592e56638e47f4950bda3bdefd08d7:0">Seven Principles of Design</span></span>

<span key="ee6871ebe1e94862aa7dfbd8ba8d6efd"><span offset-key="ee6871ebe1e94862aa7dfbd8ba8d6efd:0">There are really </span>*lots*<span offset-key="ee6871ebe1e94862aa7dfbd8ba8d6efd:2"> of useful ways to categorize and talk about design. You could come up with any arbitrary way of grouping these topics together, listing them out, and exploring them.</span></span>

<span key="7c1c651fd4ad4eb480c270590ff15cf9"><span offset-key="7c1c651fd4ad4eb480c270590ff15cf9:0">For our purposes, we're going to focus on </span>**seven principles of design**<span offset-key="7c1c651fd4ad4eb480c270590ff15cf9:2"> that combine to give us a solid foundation for approaching problems:</span></span>

-   

    <span key="5c19e339a1814167b20bf53a792dad86"><span offset-key="5c19e339a1814167b20bf53a792dad86:0">Unity</span></span>

-   

    <span key="ca852dc7ff3444e5a92133af8f0fa4b8"><span offset-key="ca852dc7ff3444e5a92133af8f0fa4b8:0">Balance</span></span>

-   

    <span key="4fd58c25f56a4cf085d3fe07f73a64ad"><span offset-key="4fd58c25f56a4cf085d3fe07f73a64ad:0">Alignment</span></span>

-   

    <span key="1d05f5b35c7a4971a31e4392513f0c39"><span offset-key="1d05f5b35c7a4971a31e4392513f0c39:0">Hierarchy</span></span>

-   

    <span key="a2c0f275772940b8b2ee134fd605d290"><span offset-key="a2c0f275772940b8b2ee134fd605d290:0">Emphasis</span></span>

-   

    <span key="fbb676ebe87e4ca68c99f40a767e3d87"><span offset-key="fbb676ebe87e4ca68c99f40a767e3d87:0">Proportion</span></span>

-   

    <span key="a3ce4d3ca0944210a6b54b7de0667fcf"><span offset-key="a3ce4d3ca0944210a6b54b7de0667fcf:0">White Space</span></span>

<span key="40ddd4d9813a46ad8a6c80b80b7d0507"><span offset-key="40ddd4d9813a46ad8a6c80b80b7d0507:0">In this module, we'll dive into each of these design principles. We'll refer to each of them throughout the rest of this course, during our Design Critiques, and throughout Labs.</span></span>

# 

<span key="b13a980be7d244f39053010ed357d8b0"><span offset-key="b13a980be7d244f39053010ed357d8b0:0">Unity</span></span>

## 

<span key="7957be46c9004d7a8950123c7308c14a"><span offset-key="7957be46c9004d7a8950123c7308c14a:0">What's Unity?</span></span>

<span key="b61cd3d47f7c46369728fb1187791101">**Unity**<span offset-key="b61cd3d47f7c46369728fb1187791101:1"> is </span>**oneness**<span offset-key="b61cd3d47f7c46369728fb1187791101:3">.</span></span>

<span key="5c9107bcbe084dbaa2fd3fff901af90c"><span offset-key="5c9107bcbe084dbaa2fd3fff901af90c:0">It's not so much about grouping things into one group, but more </span>**making things** ***one*** **thing**<span offset-key="5c9107bcbe084dbaa2fd3fff901af90c:4">. When we're talking about a group of truly independent things, unity means they fit together into a clear, logical, simple whole.</span></span>

<span key="eead6e25994a4842982651b1ec077dee"><span offset-key="eead6e25994a4842982651b1ec077dee:0">In a way, unity encapsulates all the other design principlesâ€”the rest of the concepts we'll explore need to work together to </span>**present one seamless user experience**<span offset-key="eead6e25994a4842982651b1ec077dee:2">.</span></span>

## 

<span key="5094de5ca7f34d30a94f81d3c86bfb53"><span offset-key="5094de5ca7f34d30a94f81d3c86bfb53:0">Achieving Unity</span></span>

<span key="cc44602558da4351b2c49f43e4377031"><span offset-key="cc44602558da4351b2c49f43e4377031:0">Unity takes significant conscious effort to achieveâ€”it won't happen on its own!</span></span>

<span key="b996bed97cf24ad89bd3e9b7df0baeac"><span offset-key="b996bed97cf24ad89bd3e9b7df0baeac:0">A good general approach to achieve unity is to focus on </span>**top-down design, bottom-up implementation**<span offset-key="b996bed97cf24ad89bd3e9b7df0baeac:2">.</span></span>

<span key="0aaac5e8aac24c55bb9edbef8246f470"><span offset-key="0aaac5e8aac24c55bb9edbef8246f470:0">Why? Think about this for a moment.</span></span>

<span key="217a66c53f0b40cebc7405111719a37f"><span offset-key="217a66c53f0b40cebc7405111719a37f:0">If we think about something with many parts as a whole </span>*first*<span offset-key="217a66c53f0b40cebc7405111719a37f:2">â€”even if we only have some high-level, general information to startâ€”it gives us the perspective and context we need as we proceed to implement the parts themselves.</span></span>

<span key="72516fd1a5a0475986f7963ec6aab7f2"><span offset-key="72516fd1a5a0475986f7963ec6aab7f2:0">One example would be first focusing on developing a user flow for a product, then moving on to develop wireframes for each screen, then moving on to develop individual components.</span></span>

## 

<span key="e3c7a45ce3734c04af15c436e0674116"><span offset-key="e3c7a45ce3734c04af15c436e0674116:0">Types of Unity</span></span>

<span key="2244d7609792420292585379cac0ba3f"><span offset-key="2244d7609792420292585379cac0ba3f:0">Note that the design artifact workflow we just described (user flow â†’ wireframes â†’ components) incorporates two kinds of unity: </span>**conceptual**<span offset-key="2244d7609792420292585379cac0ba3f:2"> and </span>**visual**<span offset-key="2244d7609792420292585379cac0ba3f:4"> unity.</span></span>

### 

<span key="ce50d60074fd496ea1183119c35be29f"><span offset-key="ce50d60074fd496ea1183119c35be29f:0">Conceptual Unity</span></span>

<span key="1cbe18b3a3f9452ba2147a9d8b31f973"><span offset-key="1cbe18b3a3f9452ba2147a9d8b31f973:0">Conceptual unity means that </span>*ideas*<span offset-key="1cbe18b3a3f9452ba2147a9d8b31f973:2"> fit together. In the context of a product, this could mean that as a user, if I need to perform a certain action in multiple ways, maybe I can do those actions from a single place.</span></span>

<span key="fd7517b9e2134a799ec0eeae6fc0178e"><span offset-key="fd7517b9e2134a799ec0eeae6fc0178e:0">It could also mean using consistent layouts across pages in an application, or ensuring that everything contained on a page is addressing the same set of user problems.</span></span>

### 

<span key="f45731a7247746f2b5c845e060df21f3"><span offset-key="f45731a7247746f2b5c845e060df21f3:0">Visual Unity</span></span>

<span key="709c7dcd16a44482b3e9941e3a272c15"><span offset-key="709c7dcd16a44482b3e9941e3a272c15:0">Visual unity means that </span>*visual elements*<span offset-key="709c7dcd16a44482b3e9941e3a272c15:2"> fit together. In many practical situations, it means we're working to eliminate redundancy and simplify what's presented to the user.</span></span>

<span key="17484accae864335ab5b44d6569d39b3"><span offset-key="17484accae864335ab5b44d6569d39b3:0">One example of visual unity might be to decide to only use one primary action color throughout an entire productâ€”whether it be on buttons, links, or other interactive elementsâ€”to provide an abundantly clear message to the user across contexts: "Here's how you can do something."</span></span>

<span key="4b15febdeddd45f4953ea45fddf9086a"><span offset-key="4b15febdeddd45f4953ea45fddf9086a:0">Another example might be that all of the elements on a page are consistently styled.</span></span>

<span key="9c15a5988fad4e93b2ac3e43452b3b27"><span offset-key="9c15a5988fad4e93b2ac3e43452b3b27:0">Using a design system like Ant Design helps us achieve both conceptual and visual unity by standardizing both our approaches to solve user problems and our visual implementation of those solutions.</span></span>

# 

<span key="730b3713e5cb4f03a6fc90c479f2fc19"><span offset-key="730b3713e5cb4f03a6fc90c479f2fc19:0">Balance</span></span>

## 

<span key="bffff89cd76c456fbf39af609f148973"><span offset-key="bffff89cd76c456fbf39af609f148973:0">What's Balance?</span></span>

<span key="7890d7aedbb04635a5c63200a521b32c"><span offset-key="7890d7aedbb04635a5c63200a521b32c:0">Let's turn to Merriam Webster's for this one: balance is "a state in which different things occur in equal or proper amounts or have an equal or proper amount of importance" (</span></span><a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/balance" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="3d4c84785847446d8ef7d2ea0f3d943e" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-10707_259-10708-237__"><span data-key="0ae154aa39a94910a24d483580b560e1"><span data-offset-key="0ae154aa39a94910a24d483580b560e1:0">source (Links to an external site.)</span></span></span></a><span key="38595a13da1a4186824f1831a9d07d8d"><span offset-key="38595a13da1a4186824f1831a9d07d8d:0">).</span></span>

<span key="03b131a0500d4c529580f2a21afa626d"><span offset-key="03b131a0500d4c529580f2a21afa626d:0">Note a key distinction here: balance doesn't necessarily mean that all sides of something are </span>*equal*<span offset-key="03b131a0500d4c529580f2a21afa626d:2">â€”it could just mean that everything involved has the </span>*proper*<span offset-key="03b131a0500d4c529580f2a21afa626d:4"> amount of </span>*x*<span offset-key="03b131a0500d4c529580f2a21afa626d:6">, where </span>*x*<span offset-key="03b131a0500d4c529580f2a21afa626d:8"> is something we care about. </span>*x*<span offset-key="03b131a0500d4c529580f2a21afa626d:10"> might itself be a principle of design!</span></span>

## 

<span key="5e553c499f70412c80c9f7159e4d8bbc"><span offset-key="5e553c499f70412c80c9f7159e4d8bbc:0">Symmetry</span></span>

<span key="7f8e2d14e34a4ee2a11669e5b553b22e">**Symmetry**<span offset-key="7f8e2d14e34a4ee2a11669e5b553b22e:1"> is a </span>*type*<span offset-key="7f8e2d14e34a4ee2a11669e5b553b22e:3"> of balance in which all sides of something have an </span>*equal*<span offset-key="7f8e2d14e34a4ee2a11669e5b553b22e:5"> amount of something.</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h" />

Could not load image

<span key="6a9c361acbd9421a9d50d617f81b3bcc"><span offset-key="6a9c361acbd9421a9d50d617f81b3bcc:0">Screen%20Shot%202021-08-29%20at%207.45.52%20PM.png</span></span>

<span key="c6ae631e66ff42fb8a2a470747b80038"><span offset-key="c6ae631e66ff42fb8a2a470747b80038:0">Symmetry can be visual (e.g., both columns of a page are the same height) or conceptual (e.g., if there are two major topics addressed in a web application, I can navigate a similar structure for each one).</span></span>

## 

<span key="9ea686eb367242018785409c923bcfe4"><span offset-key="9ea686eb367242018785409c923bcfe4:0">Achieving Balance</span></span>

<span key="f49cc26a8118416abc4b45c5446505d3"><span offset-key="f49cc26a8118416abc4b45c5446505d3:0">Ultimately, balance is something you'll develop an intuition for as you gain experience seeing how users react to how concepts and visual elements are arranged and presented.</span></span>

<span key="38dd04ed4d68460bbc894b1363cef3e6"><span offset-key="38dd04ed4d68460bbc894b1363cef3e6:0">To start, though, make it a point to think about balance for each design principle we'll examine. That means, for example, going out of your way to critique your own designs for balance in proportion, balance in emphasis, and balance in white space.</span></span>

<span key="a5cc6cc369ca49d79548f2ead5eb3c0c"><span offset-key="a5cc6cc369ca49d79548f2ead5eb3c0c:0">Does your design "feel" balanced in each of these ways?</span></span>

# 

<span key="0207c26fbde2483a92637b40bcfe33e2"><span offset-key="0207c26fbde2483a92637b40bcfe33e2:0">Alignment</span></span>

## 

<span key="745738e81c224f0682efc1ae55ba7444"><span offset-key="745738e81c224f0682efc1ae55ba7444:0">What's Alignment?</span></span>

<span key="6a997f4e66de4904b95302959ba00ee9"><span offset-key="6a997f4e66de4904b95302959ba00ee9:0">Alignment is one of the most critical principles of design we'll talk about, because it will apply to almost everything you design, build, and compose together in Labs.</span></span>

<span key="4d0f505b60954bf796b5c2d67737d2a4">**Alignment**<span offset-key="4d0f505b60954bf796b5c2d67737d2a4:1"> means that things </span>**line up**<span offset-key="4d0f505b60954bf796b5c2d67737d2a4:3">â€”two or more elements presented together </span>**share visual boundaries and/or centers**<span offset-key="4d0f505b60954bf796b5c2d67737d2a4:5">. You should be able to draw a few straight, imaginary lines over the visual elements you've arranged, and find that they either </span>**share a common border with**<span offset-key="4d0f505b60954bf796b5c2d67737d2a4:7"> or </span>**have symmetry across**<span offset-key="4d0f505b60954bf796b5c2d67737d2a4:9"> those lines.</span></span>

## 

<span key="40a1fc7c07724528a167af73df5fb325"><span offset-key="40a1fc7c07724528a167af73df5fb325:0">Achieving Alignment</span></span>

<span key="765d3cac82c7415887e5c17e24ba92d9"><span offset-key="765d3cac82c7415887e5c17e24ba92d9:0">Achieving alignment results from paying conscious attention to those imaginary lines. You should </span>**draw those lines during the wireframing stage**<span offset-key="765d3cac82c7415887e5c17e24ba92d9:2"> for each page or view. You don't need to </span>*literally*<span offset-key="765d3cac82c7415887e5c17e24ba92d9:4"> draw the lines, but make sure you could draw them if you wanted to.</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h" />

Could not load image

<span key="0a64c4d03deb4bdc9767200e2b8655e8"><span offset-key="0a64c4d03deb4bdc9767200e2b8655e8:0">Screen%20Shot%202021-08-29%20at%207.51.13%20PM.png</span></span>

<span key="31b0142df87d4aea9c0d88960211de69"><span offset-key="31b0142df87d4aea9c0d88960211de69:0">A very common pattern for achieving alignment in a web application is to ensure you've got </span>**consistent margins**<span offset-key="31b0142df87d4aea9c0d88960211de69:2">. For example, let's say you've got a header, a main block of content, and a footer. Impose a maximum width for the total content of the pageâ€”then make sure the left edges of each content container line up with all the rest, and likewise with the right edges. Then do the same for the </span>**vertical space**<span offset-key="31b0142df87d4aea9c0d88960211de69:4"> (padding + margin) within and between each container. See how we can draw lines here?</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h" />

Could not load image

<span key="1e858133762b471da122c8cffca57e9e"><span offset-key="1e858133762b471da122c8cffca57e9e:0">Screen%20Shot%202021-08-29%20at%207.55.21%20PM.png</span></span>

# 

<span key="1c337df587394e178bb363cf0042d5b8"><span offset-key="1c337df587394e178bb363cf0042d5b8:0">Proportion</span></span>

## 

<span key="0129298fdba94494ae367ab200c99f1c"><span offset-key="0129298fdba94494ae367ab200c99f1c:0">What's Proportion?</span></span>

<span key="e1d1faae5c234ccf9b20ef7c8fc8ab5a">**Proportion**<span offset-key="e1d1faae5c234ccf9b20ef7c8fc8ab5a:1"> is </span>**balance in scale**<span offset-key="e1d1faae5c234ccf9b20ef7c8fc8ab5a:3">.</span></span>

<span key="fc925356d07b456cb36f098026078a96"><span offset-key="fc925356d07b456cb36f098026078a96:0">Remember how we said balance would apply everywhere? Proportion is explicitly a balance property of scaleâ€”is there balance in the way elements scale?</span></span>

<span key="7a7b89b6435f4ea19ad37666aa24572a">**Scale**<span offset-key="7a7b89b6435f4ea19ad37666aa24572a:1"> is when the same or similar elements change size or show up in different sizes.</span></span>

<span key="1b86da6c7e634988b7e1e882a2487bc4"><span offset-key="1b86da6c7e634988b7e1e882a2487bc4:0">So for proportion, we want similar elements that change size or show up in different sizes to do so in a balanced way.</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h" />

Could not load image

<span key="763cb2edf6344a5a93a3acc4bf822773"><span offset-key="763cb2edf6344a5a93a3acc4bf822773:0">Screen%20Shot%202021-08-29%20at%207.59.05%20PM.png</span></span>

## 

<span key="b851823b940049f7a6bdea4602139e6e"><span offset-key="b851823b940049f7a6bdea4602139e6e:0">Using Proportion</span></span>

<span key="fc690db19cd84e2abbe63b889f36bb8c"><span offset-key="fc690db19cd84e2abbe63b889f36bb8c:0">One way to work to achieve proportion in your product is to ensure </span>**responsiveness**<span offset-key="fc690db19cd84e2abbe63b889f36bb8c:2">. Responsive design attempts to adjust content fluidly as the screen size changes. You could call this an example of </span>**dynamic**<span offset-key="fc690db19cd84e2abbe63b889f36bb8c:4"> proportion.</span></span>

<span key="a4a2602071894df6923ab9f9afcba55b"><span offset-key="a4a2602071894df6923ab9f9afcba55b:0">Another way to work toward proportion is with what you might call </span>**static**<span offset-key="a4a2602071894df6923ab9f9afcba55b:2"> proportion. If one set of elements shows up in multiple places in different sizes, the way that size has changed across instances should be consistent and balanced.</span></span>

# 

<span key="cd63ebdb53df40afa3533103733c8649"><span offset-key="cd63ebdb53df40afa3533103733c8649:0">Hierarchy</span></span>

## 

<span key="c42fa45724c1429e80f22e3a14cb9e02"><span offset-key="c42fa45724c1429e80f22e3a14cb9e02:0">What's Hierarchy?</span></span>

<span key="37416d81bca84758ad08d0b7669c77ac">**Hierarchy**<span offset-key="37416d81bca84758ad08d0b7669c77ac:1"> is the effective management of </span>**layers of abstraction**<span offset-key="37416d81bca84758ad08d0b7669c77ac:3">.</span></span>

<span key="464611219a5a447298d44bb7acfbd0c4"><span offset-key="464611219a5a447298d44bb7acfbd0c4:0">Okâ€”</span>*what on earth does that mean*<span offset-key="464611219a5a447298d44bb7acfbd0c4:2">?</span></span>

<span key="50fbfa9dd1a44175b6e866aecbc3b47f"><span offset-key="50fbfa9dd1a44175b6e866aecbc3b47f:0">You're certainly familiar with the notion of hierarchy in other contextsâ€”you've got multiple levels of something, from top to bottom. Maybe it's a filesystem with folders containing folders. Perhaps it's an organization with a CEO on the first level, then a COO on the second level, then Vice Presidents on the third level...</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h" />

Could not load image

<span key="e25a30c124b548db944bf017b3b0f10f"><span offset-key="e25a30c124b548db944bf017b3b0f10f:0">Screen%20Shot%202021-08-29%20at%208.02.25%20PM.png</span></span>

<span key="6b6aebe6b36140ad921c343b1f4f0637"><span offset-key="6b6aebe6b36140ad921c343b1f4f0637:0">This is the </span>*concept*<span offset-key="6b6aebe6b36140ad921c343b1f4f0637:2"> of hierarchy, and a chart like the above is one way to illustrate hierarchy visually as well.</span></span>

## 

<span key="96d8e267b00a4879b90b8730c934bc2b"><span offset-key="96d8e267b00a4879b90b8730c934bc2b:0">Using Hierarchy</span></span>

<span key="a3bc9ff788ee46c79ba32f111dd961c3"><span offset-key="a3bc9ff788ee46c79ba32f111dd961c3:0">Really, though, hierarchy goes way beyond that in design. For example, think about heading levels in HTML or a text editorâ€”this is a form of hierarchy, right?</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h" />

Could not load image

<span key="ba530b97be3a4465a46f4e2991caa3f7"><span offset-key="ba530b97be3a4465a46f4e2991caa3f7:0">Screen%20Shot%202021-08-29%20at%208.05.26%20PM.png</span></span>

<span key="a4d9311d3d7740189c49dbd6f7d2155a"><span offset-key="a4d9311d3d7740189c49dbd6f7d2155a:0">To leverage hierarchy effectively in design, </span>**think about how you can organizeâ€”first conceptually, then visuallyâ€”your content into layers of abstraction.**</span>

<span key="e6f869df9b9d45e0a596553ac9646c22"><span offset-key="e6f869df9b9d45e0a596553ac9646c22:0">This also includes </span>**the actions a user can take**<span offset-key="e6f869df9b9d45e0a596553ac9646c22:2"> on the pageâ€”maybe there's one main, "primary" action they can take, a few still-significant "secondary" actions they can take... how can you make this hierarchy of action importance clear to your user?</span></span>

# 

<span key="b8542a3befa64934b664da375daefa0e"><span offset-key="b8542a3befa64934b664da375daefa0e:0">Emphasis</span></span>

## 

<span key="9ad0f699337649d38232fa2232c9836f"><span offset-key="9ad0f699337649d38232fa2232c9836f:0">What's Emphasis?</span></span>

<span key="4f356e504cb3402ca8a237aa69427b21">**Emphasis**<span offset-key="4f356e504cb3402ca8a237aa69427b21:1"> is effectively directing your users' attention.</span></span>

<span key="a7067a69f95646ebb52505937ece42b5"><span offset-key="a7067a69f95646ebb52505937ece42b5:0">What word in this sentence are you </span>**drawn**<span offset-key="a7067a69f95646ebb52505937ece42b5:2"> to? Does reading this </span>**sentence**<span offset-key="a7067a69f95646ebb52505937ece42b5:4"> feel natural?</span></span>

<span key="a349becf1ceb4537abfbc8e27b809a0a"><span offset-key="a349becf1ceb4537abfbc8e27b809a0a:0">You can influence where your users direct their attention in many waysâ€”some quite subtle.</span></span>

## 

<span key="8203046f80e44b21b68b5f1048fc4e7c"><span offset-key="8203046f80e44b21b68b5f1048fc4e7c:0">Using Emphasis</span></span>

<span key="c8e80e667d474ff78ff9276ec3adb056"><span offset-key="c8e80e667d474ff78ff9276ec3adb056:0">Emphasis isn't just emphasizing words with tools like font size and weight, italics, and underlining. It's also the choices you make about what visual elements to include where, the use of color, the use of borders, and the incorporation of all the other principles of design to consciously control the flow of attention.</span></span>

<span key="cbf0c5e5cb474d0b8dbb7f5be78c275c"><span offset-key="cbf0c5e5cb474d0b8dbb7f5be78c275c:0">For example, where is your attention drawn in the following image:</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h" />

Could not load image

<span key="b884dc9558b24831b027174968030678"><span offset-key="b884dc9558b24831b027174968030678:0">Screen%20Shot%202021-08-29%20at%208.11.20%20PM.png</span></span>

<span key="588fbdf14c594b208603d3330d8e5664"><span offset-key="588fbdf14c594b208603d3330d8e5664:0">How about this one?</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h" />

<span key="719f8d699ce64bcf9cb058fea1f2af12"><span offset-key="719f8d699ce64bcf9cb058fea1f2af12:0">Notice how principles like hierarchy, proportion, and balance factor into leveraging emphasis to achieve your design goals.</span></span>

# 

<span key="53943327e4844c05ade607d3a8580d03"><span offset-key="53943327e4844c05ade607d3a8580d03:0">White Space</span></span>

## 

<span key="527e8853394144f2a4d0572f1bbf770e"><span offset-key="527e8853394144f2a4d0572f1bbf770e:0">What's White Space?</span></span>

<span key="876fe47fea804d11b4bf9e1550004a4d">**White space**<span offset-key="876fe47fea804d11b4bf9e1550004a4d:1"> (or </span>**negative space**<span offset-key="876fe47fea804d11b4bf9e1550004a4d:3">) is the space between and around elements.</span></span>

<span key="26098d52d7324d5080b8601070f35c65"><span offset-key="26098d52d7324d5080b8601070f35c65:0">The concept of white space has been explored and leveraged by artists for millenniaâ€”the conscious use of "nothing" is a way to incorporate all the other design principles.</span></span>

<span key="554ef4abdcb24ffbabee2e49eb42da56"><span offset-key="554ef4abdcb24ffbabee2e49eb42da56:0">Notice how white space influences our attention and our perception in the following layout:</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h" />

Could not load image

<span key="c0c7b84604844d059a8f9539a19a274c"><span offset-key="c0c7b84604844d059a8f9539a19a274c:0">Screen%20Shot%202021-08-29%20at%208.20.07%20PM.png</span></span>

## 

<span key="1e649a343e6b44f0bf7894d4e33f525c"><span offset-key="1e649a343e6b44f0bf7894d4e33f525c:0">Using White Space</span></span>

<span key="8a440610f408451a951d6c4613822664"><span offset-key="8a440610f408451a951d6c4613822664:0">The key to using white space is to remember to use it in the first place!</span></span>

<span key="a511831b08e7407aabc6431a1292b3f0"><span offset-key="a511831b08e7407aabc6431a1292b3f0:0">Since white space is the absence of an element, you can use it to direct your user's attention to the elements that \_are\_present. Ensure there's enough space between elements to make each stand out (emphasis!), that your patterns of using white space are consistent (unity and balance!), and that any visual hierarchies (!) use spacing in predictable ways.</span></span>
